Headline: Compliance Expert | Business Strategist | Startup Consultant | IP advisor
Comment:
Founders often forget that money is not the solution, it is the amplifier. If the product is not ready, raising capital just makes the cracks bigger. Chasing growth too early usually ends with rushed hires, poor retention, and short-term choices that cost long-term trust.
There is nothing wrong with waiting. Build depth, let users stick around without incentives, and get your numbers to speak for themselves. When the foundation is solid, capital accelerates growth. When it is not, it only speeds up the chaos.

Comment:
A kurti should earn its place in the rotation - not live in the back of the wardrobe.

We‚Äôre Karma Clothing ,  a founder-led Delhi label building premium, pure-cotton kurtis with one practical obsession: they must work in real life.
We focus on the small, often-ignored details that change everyday behaviour: breathable fabric, honest fits, and real pockets placed where you‚Äôll actually use them. Add small-batch runs (no overproduction), transparent workmanship, and fair pricing ‚Äî and you get pieces people reach for again and again.

Why it matters:
‚Ä¢ Comfort = repeat wear ‚Äî pure cotton that breathes in Indian weather.
‚Ä¢ Pockets that perform ‚Äî tiny design choice, huge daily payoff (phone, keys, chai).
‚Ä¢ Small-batch & local ‚Äî better quality control, less waste, more exclusivity.
‚Ä¢ Fair pricing ‚Äî premium feel without premium shock.

People don‚Äôt buy another kurti from us because it‚Äôs trendy ‚Äî they buy it because it becomes their go-to. If that sounds like the kind of product you believe in, follow Karma Clothing  or DM us for a sample, pop-up collab, or wholesale conversation.

Headline: Chief Executer @ iGo | Mobility technologies for the next 6 billion!
Comment:
We had the same thought process back in 2021 when we felt we were not ready to raise.

At the peak of the EV hype cycle, most investors were funding random startups out of FOMO without understanding the timelines required for hard-tech.

And a bit later, the funding winter hits all of us. Most investors go into the corrective phase.

Bottomline: It is not one size fits all. Evaluate relevance for yourself. More importantly, the question is not when to raise. The real question is whom to raise from. That's what matters!

Headline: Curating India‚Äôs Most Exclusive Experiences ‚õ∑ | Founder @ Secret Ski Party | Building Experiential IPs in the Himalayas | Hotelier | Entrepreneur | Redefining the Future of Luxury
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala  I‚Äôve turned down funding. Multiple times.
Because I knew the cost.

With capital comes pressure: scale faster, hire quicker, hit vanity metrics to justify the valuation. But I wasn‚Äôt building a startup. I was building something cultural. Timeless. With depth.

I‚Äôve seen too many great ideas get rushed, diluted, or destroyed because the money arrived before the soul was ready.

Sometimes the bravest thing you can do as a founder is say:
‚ÄúNot yet.‚Äù

Let the product mature.
Let the numbers compound without performance pressure.

When you finally take on capital from a place of clarity, it amplifies.

The premature capital infusion can often create a 'solution in search of a problem,' forcing founders to fit their product into a narrative that doesn't yet exist. The post highlights that the most successful companies are often those that resist external pressure and stay grounded in their initial mission‚Äîproving their core value to a small, dedicated user base first. The best 'market fit' isn't measured by a funding round, but by the natural, unprompted retention of your early adopters.
